awd_titl_txt: Conferences on Discrete Geometry and Algebraic Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a four-day Conference in Discrete Geometry and Algebraic Combinatorics to be held from April 29 to May 2, 2019 in South Padre Island, TX. The conference, the 10th in a series, is devoted to a wide range of classical and modern problems in these active areas of mathematical research. The conferences bring together students and researchers in the region centered at the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley. Due to the diverse composition of the student body, conference organizers expect to be able to attract a sizable fraction of attendees from among groups traditionally underrepresented in U.S. mathematics studies. The grant provides travel support for graduate students and early-career researchers, as well as non-local participants without other sources of support. 

Topics to be discussed at the conference include packings, coverings, and tilings; rigidity and flexibility; geometric graph theory; topological combinatorics; incidence structures; lattices and discrete groups; geometric set partitioning and transversals; optimal configurations; spherical and Euclidean designs; semidefinite and linear programming in coding theory and discrete geometry.  More information is available at the conference website www.utrgv.edu/discgeo.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under this award, two conferences on Discrete Geometry and Algebraic Combinatorics were organized in the Rio Grande Valley.

The tenth conference in the series took place in September 2019 on South Padre Island, TX. The eleventh conference in the series took place in February 2024 at the Brownsville campus of the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley.

During the conferences, 30 talks were given by invited experts and local participants. Around half of the talks were given by students, postdocs, and junior researchers. The highlight of the tenth conference was a public lecture for a wide audience delivered by Jesús A. De Loera (University of California, Davis). Cumulatively, more than 100 UTRGV students participated in conference activities in 2019 and 2024. Overall, the conferences provided a great venue for students and researchers at the beginning stages of their careers to get familiar with current advancements in the areas of combinatorics and discrete geometry.

Contributing to the broader impacts of the project, the conferences were organized in the Rio Grande Valley, a region with a predominantly Hispanic population in South Texas. A majority of UTRGV students are Hispanic and first-generation. The conferences supported by this project allowed students from these underrepresented communities to be introduced to the areas of combinatorics and discrete geometry.
